text: Family Member: Is that good for him to be taking? Doctor: Yeah. No. You’re on a medicine that interacts with everything known to mankind. XTANDI is, remember we talked about how it’s processed through the liver? So it’d be good if you don’t add on extra stuff that will tax your liver that would make the XTANDI either work less or more. More is not necessarily better, and it might make you have more side effects. Family Member: Have you heard of fluorescence? Doctor: Never heard of it. But in general we try to stay away from too many supplements on drugs like XTANDI because it is a known interactor Family Member: Oh. Oh. It’s not a drug. It’s like a homeopathic. Doctor: of many existing drugs. You have to be careful. Right. But all of those are drugs. They really are. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: However you want to bill it and put it in a nice package, anything you take is a potential drug swirling around in your bloodstream. Family Member: Hm Mmm. Doctor: How much, how little, we don’t know. So at the moment, while you’re on other treatment, I wouldn’t advise it. Okay? Family Member: It could nullify the treatment? Doctor: Yeah. Or make it worse.

XTANDI is, remember we talked about how it’s processed through the liver? So it’d be good if you don’t add on extra stuff that will tax your liver that would make the XTANDI either work less or more. More is not necessarily better, and it might make you have more side effects. Family Member: Have you heard of fluorescence? Doctor: Never heard of it. But in general we try to stay away from too many supplements on drugs like XTANDI because it is a known interactor Family Member: Oh. Oh. It’s not a drug. It’s like a homeopathic. Doctor: of many existing drugs. You have to be careful. Right. But all of those are drugs. They really are. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: However you want to bill it and put it in a nice package, anything you take is a potential drug swirling around in your bloodstream. Family Member: Hm Mmm. Doctor: How much, how little, we don’t know. So at the moment, while you’re on other treatment, I wouldn’t advise it. Okay? Family Member: It could nullify the treatment? Doctor: Yeah. Or make it worse.

text: Patient: Yes. And I took one when I got here, too. I didn’t write it down. I took one after I got here because I could feel in my thighs, so I did take one, uh, when we got to the, to, the facility today. Doctor: Do you think the experimental drug is working? The Patient: Oh, I, I know it’s working. I believe it is. Doctor: And what makes you think that it’s working? Patient: I believe it from the perspective of where I was having pain at and not, uh, from a perspective of, uh, uh, uh, uh, since we lowered the doses- Doctor: Um hum. Patient: That I’ve been feeling pretty good for the most part. Uh, just as long as I don’t overexert myself. And that’s one of the biggest things, that, you know, you’re feeling good. And you said, okay, I’m going to do a little extra today, and that may be a no-no. You know? So I, you know, even at my church, I got up and, uh, I think that was two Sundays ago or three Sundays ago, and, uh, I stayed up too long and I preached too hard. And I paid for it the next twenty-four hours of doing it. I should have just cut it short. So what I do now, is like last week, they had church conference meeting. And I came up on Saturday for church conference meeting to let them know I wasn’t coming up for Sunday services and had one of my associates to – Doctor: Okay. Patient: -to to, because I can’t do both. Because it’s like I will drive to go up. Really it’s an hour and fifteen minutes and an hour and fifteen minutes to go back. Uh, it’s a long day. And that’s a lot to be in that car. So, uh, I learned the hard way. So, uh, my plan now is always to use them if I have to, uh, but, uh, I can’t overdo it because I’ll pay for it the next, the next day. It comes back on me. Doctor: So there’s a bit of a disconnect in terms of some of the things that we’re seeing and, and some of the ways that you’re feeling. And I’m not a hundred percent sure like in my own mind whether this drug is working or not. That’s why I asked you what you’ve been thinking. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, the parts of me that make me think that it’s not working as well as we expected it is that the PSA level continues to increase. Patient: Um hum.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now one question that patients always ask me is “Is it possible you know for the uh testosterone to make the cancer worse?” In other words, could it accelerate or stimulate or speed up the cancer? Patient: Uh huh. My thoughts also. Doctor: And you know that was one of the very first things we thought of when we were designing these trials for uh patients and the first trial of this approach started in around twenty thirteen. And so we’ve been doing this for three or four years now. And in our initial studies, fortunately we did not see any cases where prostate cancer appeared to accelerate. Patient: Oh okay. Doctor: So we basically saw one of three patterns. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So the first is, which is the most promising, is that the cancer goes into remission. That’s about one-third of patients. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And then in about one-third of patients, the cancer neither grows nor shrinks. So it basically stabilizes. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And that stabilization typically lasts anywhere from six to twelve months. So it’s not permanent. Patient: Uh huh.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: It could be a cancer spot. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Or it could be that you bled into your adrenal gland, and so, uh, hemorrhaged into the adrenal gland. Was that your aspirin? You know, I don’t know why people do that. But you can spontaneously do that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. Is it a side effect of the drug? I don’t know. But is it a cancer spot? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. So, let’s go to the data. You are on therapy, really tolerating it okay? Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And I would say, no worse for the wear? Patient: Nope. Doctor: Um, we have scans that are sort of trending worse but nothing definitively worse --- by new other than the adrenal thing, and that is hedging. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: You know, it was a little, uh I was really hoping that this would start the numbers to decrease, that was what I was anticipating at the very beginning, but I knew there was a possibility that they would be going up. So just a little disappointed – Doctor: Yeah. Patient: - that they have been going up. I think that the thing that kept me most uh calm with it was that they weren’t increasing you know as fast as they were before I went You know a person coming into the study with um, I think it was around four when I really started noticing the stuff going and now we’re somewhere around twenty-eight, twenty-nine. Family Member: Twenty-eight. Patient: Yeah. So you know. But that was (chuckles) Doctor: But it, it has slowed down a little bit, you know we design studies you know, we want things to slow down but really what we want to see is you know, huge and immediate increases. So we always sort of go for the home run and then sometimes you know we might get a single and double, Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: but you really want to go for the home run. So we do not have a home run. We all know that by now. We have patients on this study where um they get the same drug you’ve got or the same dose – Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: - and their PSA drops by ninety-eight percent in the first two months. We’ve seen that. You’re not one of those guys. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We also have other people where the PSA continues to increase at the same pace or in some people it even speeds up. So you’re not in that category either. Then we have some people where the PSA you know slows down, they stay on the drug for anywhere between four to six months. It’s probably doing something, but it’s not know the desired effect or the absolute you know, perfect effect that we expected, so it’s sort of a middle ground, and yet it’s hard to justify you know to keep going if all you’re seeing is like a lukewarm type of response. Patient: Right, right, right.

It’s probably doing something, but it’s not know the desired effect or the absolute you know, perfect effect that we expected, so it’s sort of a middle ground, and yet it’s hard to justify you know to keep going if all you’re seeing is like a lukewarm type of response. Patient: Right, right, right.

text: Patient: Oh, of course. Doctor: You know, so we want you to be ready. What I want is for that to be in your medicine cabinet. Family Member 1: If his gums are sensitive, can I call M___ too? Doctor: Yep, yes. And you know you could gargle with salt water to just keep that bacteria moving out of there. So there's no sort of overdose on warm saltwater. Family Member 1: How about hydrogen peroxide, diluted? Doctor: That's hard. Family Member 1: Oh okay. Doctor: See that's hard because any alcohol based products for our mouths are bad. Family Member 1: There’s alcohol, I forgot. Doctor: So it's a challenge for cancer patients. So like if you look at Listerine or Crest they have now the non alcohol version. So you could try that. Family Member 1: He likes to gargle with Listerine. Doctor: Yeah, there's a non alcohol version of Listerine.

Doctor: Yeah, there's a non alcohol version of Listerine.

text: Family Member 1: Could he wear a mask if he wanted? Doctor: He could but just it's challenging to do that because you're kind of have the baby right here. You’re hugging her. Patient: Uh I don’t think Family Member 1: She’s two years old. He lifts her up the crib. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: But we're worried can she get cancer from him? Like from being around him? Doctor: No, she can't get sick from him. Family Member 1: Write that down. Doctor: It's more like she’s going to be tough for you. And the mask can only do so much. Family Member 1: In case she picks up a virus from her. Family Member 2: She goes to classes around other kids. Doctor: Absolutely. Family Member 2: Can the mask cover it?

text: Family Member: Right. Doctor: Once you’ve had a CRYO, we automatically keep the CAT scans that have had CRYO for the person who did the CRYO to read. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
